column2: I have at times changed opinions that were important to me, when someone showed me I was wrong.
column3: I am willing to change my position on an important issue in the face of good reasons.
column4: I am open to revising my important beliefs in the face of new information.
column5: I am willing to change my opinions on the basis of compelling reason.
column6: I’m willing to change my mind once it’s made up about an important topic.
column7: When scientists change their mind about a scientific idea it diminishes my trust in their work.
column8: Scientists ignore evidence that contradicts their work.
column10: Scientists intentionally keep their work secret.
column11: We can trust scientists to share their discoveries even if they don't like their findings.
column12: Scientists don't value the ideas of others.
column13: I trust that the work of scientists is to make life better for people.
column14: Scientists don't care if laypersons understand their work.
column15: We should trust the work of scientists.
column16: We should trust that scientists are being honest in their work.
column17: We should trust that scientists are being ethical in their work.
column19: When scientists form a hypothesis they are just guessing.
column20: People who understand science more have more trust in science.
column21: We can trust science to find the answers that explain the natural world.
column22: I trust scientists can find solutions to our major technological problems.
column23: We cannot trust scientists because they are biased in their perspectives.
column24: Scientists will protect each other even when they are wrong.
column25: We cannot trust scientists to consider ideas that contradict their own.
column26: Today's scientists will sacrifice the well being of others to advance their research.
column27: We cannot trust science because it moves too slowly.
column28: If you wish to comment about the questions in this survey, you may do so here. You are not required to comment. Your comments might be seen by others.
